item.title: Congo rebel leader claims responsibility for drone attack on strategic northeast city
item.description:
Feb 3 (Reuters) - The leader of the AFC/M23 rebel movement in Democratic Republic of Congo on Tuesday claimed responsibility on social media for a drone attack targeting the airport in the strategic northeastern city of Kisangani.

The government of Tshopo province, where Kisangani is located, said in a statement on Sunday that eight explosive‑laden drones had targeted the airport serving Kisangani.

item.title: Saif Islam Gadhafi, son of late Libyan ruler, killed in gunfight: What to know
item.description: Gadhafi was a key figure in his father Moammar Gadhafi's regime, and faced legal prosecution for his alleged roles in crimes against Libyans.

item.title: UK's Starmer discussed Ukraine in call with Trump, British government says
item.description:
Feb 3 (Reuters) - British Prime Minister Keir Starmer spoke to U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday and discussed the situation in Ukraine, including the overnight Russian attacks on the country, the UK government said.

Russia's overnight attack knocked out heating in cities including the capital Kyiv during freezing temperatures as Ukrainian negotiators headed to Abu Dhabi for a second round of U.S.-brokered trilateral talks set for Wednesday and Thursday.

The leaders also recognizedthe strategic importance of the U.S.-UK military base Diego Garcia, the governmentadded.

item.title: US-Iran talks uncertain as Tehran pushes to sideline regional countries
item.description: Iran is also pushing to move the negotiations to Oman and to exclude its missile program from the talks.

item.title: Iraq’s Maliki rejects Trump criticism, vows to stay in PM race
item.description: Maliki refused to withdraw from the race, despite mounting pressure from the US, and expressed a desire for good relations with Iraq’s neighbors and Washington.

item.title: US, Iran weigh de-escalation declaration as first step of talks
item.description: Behind the scenes, Iran and the United States are exploring a cautious diplomatic track centered on de-escalation rather than immediate concessions.

item.title: Bracing for backlash, Iran sends mixed signals on US talks
item.description: Iran's public messaging remains fragmented, with cautious openness from the presidency, rigid red lines from security officials and outright rejection from hard-liners, who see negotiations as futile.
